OaqaAma He observed, or duly performed, a religious, or moral, ordinance or duty.

OaqaAma AlbayRinapa [He established the evidence or proof; and so AqAm bihaA? the b being redundant]. (Bd, iii. 68.) And [in like manner,] AqAm HujRatahu i. q. OavobatahaA; (TA in art. vbt;) and so, app., biHujRatihi; the b being redundant, as in an ex. voce xuTRapN; but this is the only ex. that I know, and it is without explanation: Golius mentions the phrase OaqaAma biI Ealayokumo; but without indicating his authority.

OaqaAma EalaI HaAlK He abode, or continued, in a state, or condition; and AqAm ElI OamorK the same; and he abode, continued, stayed, or waited, intent upon, or occupied in, an affair, a business, or a concern; he kept to it.
5. taqawRama It subsisted: see rukonN.

s.hi: It had a price; was valued.

sense.s: See 2.
6. taqaAwamuwhu fiymaA bayonahumo They valued it, or estimated its price, among them. (TA.)
10. AisotaqaAma It became right; direct; in a right state; straight: even: tended towards the right, or desired, point, or object; had a right direction, or tendency; was regular.
AisotaqaAma EalaI Tariyqi AlHaqRi (K, art. rXd) He continued in the way of truth, or the right way; as also Ealayohi
OaqaAma?
lamo yasotaqimi AlOamoru The affair was, or became, difficult: see taEacRara.
AstqAm lahu AlOamoru The affair, or case, became in a right state for him; syn. AiEotadala. (S.)

AisotaqaAma He, or it, was, or became, right, direct, rightly directed, undeviating, straight, or even: and he, or it, stood right, or straight, or erect. (MA, KL.) He went right on, straight on, or undeviatingly: (see zaEaba:) whence AisotaqaAma EalaI AlTRariyqapi he went on undeviatingly in the way. (See Kur lxxii. 16.) He went right; pursued a right course; acted rightly, or justly. See also sadRa, with which it is syn. It (an affair) was direct in its tendency, or had a right tendency. It (discourse, &c.) had a right tenour.
See 2.

qawomN [A people, or body of persons composing a community: and people, or persons:] a company, or body, [or party, (see what follows,)] of men, [properly] without women: (S, Msb, K, &c.:) or of men and women together; (K;) for the qwm of every man is his party, and his kinsfolk, or tribe: (TA:) or (K) sometimes including women, as followers; (S, Msb, K;) for the qwm of every prophet is of men and women. (S, Msb.)
qawomN opposed to nisaMCN: see a verse cited voce sawofa.
qaAmapN The stature of a man; his height in a standing posture; it is a span (Xibor) shorter than a bAE: (JK:) tallness, height; and beauty, or justness, of stature. (K.)

qaAmapN A structure [or post] like the figure of a man, raised at the side of a well, whereon is placed the wood to which the pulley is attached: pl. qaAmN: (JK:) also called qaAYimapN↓: see K, voce Eamuwd: or qaAmapu AlbakorapN signifies the sheave (bakorap) with its apparatus. (S, K.)
diynN qiyamN A right religion. (Kur, vi. 162.) See dirRapN.
AlrRiyaAHu AlquwRamu The right [or cardinal] winds. (S, voce nakobaACu.)
AldRiynu AlqayRimu (Kur ix. 36) The right, correct, or true, reckoning. (T in art. dyn.)
qayRimu AlOamori i. q. muqiymuhu↓ and saAYisuhu: fem. qayRimapN. (TA.)
qayRimN biAlOamori A manager of an affair; i. q. UizaAWuhu. (S, Msb, art. AzI.) See qaAma biAlOamori.

qayRimN A manager, conductor, orderer, regulator, or superintendent, of an affair: (TA:) a manager, conductor, &c., of the affairs of a people. (JK.) qayRimN EalaI AlmaAli A good [manager and] tender of camels, &c. (TA in art. blw.)
qiymapN The real value, or worth, of a thing; its equivalent; differing from vamanN, q. v. (MF in art. vmn.)
qawaAmN Stature, and goodly stature, or tallness, of a man: (S:) symmetry, or justness of proportion. (Msb.)

qiwaAmu AlOamori and qiyaAmuhu and qawaAmuhu The stay, or support, of the thing, or affair, whereby it subsists, and is managed and ordered. (Msb.) And qiwaAmN The food that is a man's support; (Msb;) [his subsistence.]
qiwaAmN [The main stay of a thing.]
laA qiwaAma lahu bihi [He has not power to withstand him. (K, art. njz.)
qiwaAmN Subsistence: see rukonN and TabaEN.
qiyaAmN [A state of purging, or flux of the belly: used in this sense in the S, K, voce hayoDapN].
qawiymN: see SawiybN.
AlqayRuwmu: see yaA qayRuwmu in the last paragraph of art. Xrh, where I have rendered it on the authority of an explanation in the TA.
qawRaAmN One who rises much, or often, in the night to pray. (TA.) See SawRaAmN.
quwmiyRapN is written with damm in copies of the S, K, JK: in the CK, erroneously, qawomiyRapN, in both senses. See voce mutaXamRisN.
qaAYimN Appearing; conspicuous; [as though standing before one]: said of a thing whether standing or thrown down. (TA, in explanation of the phrase hecaA nuSobu EayoniI, art. nSb.)
qaAYimapN, pl. qawaAYimu, Leg of a horse, &c.

EayonN qaAYimapN An eye [blind, or white and blind, but still whole or] that has become white and blind, but not yet burst, (AZ in L, art. sd,) or sightless, but with the black still remaining. (Mgh, Msb.)
qaAYimN and qaAYimapN The hilt of a sword. (Msb.)
qaAYimapN A leg of a table, and of a throne, or moveable seat, &c. (JK.) See also qaAmapN; and see UisonaAdN.
qawamapu bayoti AlnRaAri (K, art. hrbc.) The servants of the fire-temple. (TA, same art.)
AlqawaAYimu The winds. So in a verse of Umeiyeh Ibn-Abi-s-Salt. (TA, voce sadirN.)
qawaAYimu AlmaAYidapi [The legs of the table]. (K, art. Eqr.)
qaTRN qaAYimN A nibbing in which the pith and the exterior of the reed are made of equal length: opposed to muSawRabN. (TA in art. Hrf.)
maMCN qaAYimN Frozen water. And stagnant water: see HibaAk.

UiqaAmapN The form of words chanted by the mubalRig, not by the muWacRin, consisting of the common words of the OacaAn, with the addition of qado qaAmati AlSRalaApu (The time of prayer has come!) pronounced twice after HaIRa EalaI AlfalaAHi. See vawRaba.

maqaAmN The place of the feet; (K;) a standingplace; (S, Msb;) as also muqaAmN↓: (S:) or the latter, a place of stationing: (Msb:) and both, a place of continuance, stay, residence, or abode: (K:) [a standing:] and the latter, a place of long continuance, stay, residence, or abode: (Expos. of the Mo'allakát, Calc., p. 138:) and both, continuance, stay, residence, or abode. (S, K.)
muqaAmN: see maqaAmN.
muqiymN Lasting; continuing: (Bd, ix. 21:) unceasing. (Bd, ix. 69.)
Oaxacahu Almuqiymu AlmuqoEidu: see art. qEd.
See qayRimN.

maqaAmapN A standing-place. Hence, (assumed tropical:) A sittingplace. Hence, (assumed tropical:) The persons sitting there. Hence, (assumed tropical:) An oration, or a discourse, or an exhortation, (xuTobap Aw EiZap,) or the like, there delivered; as also majolisN. (Mtr, in De Sacy's ed. of El-Hareeree, p. 5.)
HajarN mutaqawRimN (K, art. mws) A precious stone. (TA, same art.)
taqowiymaAtN [pl. of taqowiymN] Stellar calculations. (TA, voce AiyjN.)
quwhapN: see fuwRahapN, last sentence.
1. qawiIa and taqawRaI↓ (S, K) and AiqotawaI↓ (K) He became strong: (S, K:) vigorous, robust, or sturdy; like AiXotadRa, or the last signifies he became excellent in strength. (TA.)

qawiIa Ealayohi He had strength, or power, sufficient for it; or he had strength, or power, to endure it; he prevailed against it; namely, travel, adversity, &c. And He or it, prevailed over him, or it.
See 4.

qawiIa is [said to be] originally qawiwa, because it is from AlquwRapu: (I'Ak, p. 368:) but Lth holds quwRapN to be [anomalous,] originally quwyapN. (TA.) I prefer the former opinion, and think it should be mentioned in art. qw, or I would rather head this art. qw or qwI, like gw or gwI. ISd holds quwRapN to be from qww, like vuwRapN, q. v. from vww.
2. qawRaAhu: see XadRahu.
qawRaAniI Ealayohi: see 2 in art. Twq.
3. qaAwaAhu He vied with him, strove to surpass him, or contended with him for superiority, (S, K,) in strength: (TA:) i. q. XaAdRahu. (A, L in art. Xd.)
4. Oaqowati AldRaAru The house became empty, vacant, or unoccupied; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) as also qawiyat↓. (S, K.)
5. taqawRaI He strengthened himself; made himself, or constrained himself to be, strong; affected, or endeavoured to acquire, strength. See 1.
taqawRaI mina AlXRaIoCi biqawomihi: see tamanRaEa.
8: see 1.
fuwRapN Strength, power, potency, might, or force; contr. of DaEofN; (S, K;) in body, and in intellect: (TA:) vigour, robustness, or sturdiness; like XidRap.

quwRapN A strand; i. e., a single twist of a rope; a yarn; a distinct, and separately twisted, portion, of two or more which, being twisted together, compose the whole, of a rope, and of a string, or thread. See also vinoIN.
A faculty. Ex. AlsRamoEu quwRapN fiI AlAucuni bihaA tudoriku AlOaSowaAta [AlsmE is a faculty in the ear by which it perceives sounds]. (TA in art. smE.)
biAlquwRapi Potentially, or virtually; as opposed to biAlfiEoli, i. e. actually.
quwRapu lafoZK: see layota.
bitRu qawiyFA, and qaAwiyFA, and muqowiyFA: see gawFI and gawiIRN in art. gw.
qayRaAsN: see qawRaAsN.
maqiysN (not muqayRasN) Consistent with analogy.
miqoyaSN: see maqowasN.
1. qaADa: see AnqAS, art. qyS.
7. UinoqaADa: see AnqAS, art. qyS.
munoqaADN: see munoqaASN.
qayoZiIRN: on the nitaAj thus called see SafariIRN.

qiyqaMCN, (K, voce talotalapN; S, K, voce rafaDa, and voce waliyEN; K, voce jufRN; &c.,) or qiyqaMCapN, (S, voce talotalapN; and TA,) and qiyqaOapN, (TA,) or qiyqaApN and qiyqaAyapN, (JK,) The envelope (qiXor, JK, or wiEaMC, TA) of the TaloE [or spadix of the palm-tree]; (JK, TA;) which is made into a drinking-vessel, like the talotalap: (JK:) the qiyqaMC of the TaloE is the envelope (giXaMC) that is with the waliyE. (K, voce jufRN.)
qiyqN and see faAqN.
quyAaqN: see faAqN.
qyqAC see voce HarabN and K, voce waliyEN and jufRN.
1. qaAla He slept during midday: (Mgh:) or he stayed during midday. (TA, art. hjr.)
qayRala: see another meaning, voce bayRata.
3. qaAyalahu AlbayoEa [He dissolved, rescinded, or annulled, with him the sale]. (A, art. rd.)

4. OaqaAla QllRehu Eavorataka, and EivAaraka, [May God cancel thy slip, lapse, fault, wrong action, or mistake: (A, art. Evr:) may God raise thee from thy fall. (Msb, art. qyl.) OaqaAlahu Eavoratahu He forgave him his slip, lapse, or fault. (MA.)
5. taqayRala OabaAhu: see taqayRaDa and taOasRala.

10. AisotaqAala AlbayoEa He desired, or demanded, the rescinding of the sale, or purchase. (MA.) And AstqAl AlEanowapu He desired, or demanded, his passing over, or forgiving, the slip, lapse, or fault. (MA.) See also Har, p. 7. See also a verse cited voce EanowapN.
qaAYilapN: see gaAaYirahN.

maqiylN A resting-place; syn. musotaqarRN: hence, maqiylu AlHubRi [the resting-place of love] and maqiylu AlgayoZi [the resting-place of wrath], applied by El-Mutanebbee to the heart. (W, i. 112.) See an ex. (mistranslated) in De Sacy's Ar. Gr., sec. ed., ii. 165: the same, with a var., in Ibn-Akeel p. 210.
qayonN The part, of a camel, that is the place of the shackle, or hobble. (Ham, p. 558.) See a verse of Dhu-r-Rummeh, voce daAnaI.
